SEARCH
Package com.autograd

Class Value

java.lang.Object
com.autograd.Value
public class Value extends Object

The Autograd Engine

The big question in neural networks: "If I change this one number a tiny bit, how much does the overall error change?" The answer is called a "gradient."

The Value class wraps every number and secretly records every math operation done to it — building a chain. When you call Backward(), it walks backward through that chain to figure out each number's influence on the final error.

This technique is called "backpropagation." It's the core of how neural networks learn. In production, PyTorch or TensorFlow does this on tensors (big arrays of numbers) on GPUs. Here we do it one scalar at a time.

Think of it like a spreadsheet: if cell Z depends on Y, which depends on X, and you change X by 0.001, how much does Z change? The chain rule from calculus answers this automatically for any chain of operations.

  • Field Details

    • data

      public double data
      The actual number (e.g. 0.37, -1.2, etc.)

    • grad

      public double grad
      The gradient: "how much does the final error change if I nudge this number?" Starts at 0, gets filled in during backward().

    • _backward

      private Runnable _backward
      A runnable that computes this node's contribution to gradients. Each operation (+, *, exp, etc.) defines its own gradient rule.

    • _prev

      private final Set<Value> _prev
      The Values that were inputs to the operation that created this Value. This is how we track the computation graph — like a family tree of math.

    • op

      public final String op
      What operation created this node ("+", "*", "exp", etc.) — for debugging.

  • Constructor Details

    • Value

      public Value(double data)
      Creates a new Value with no inputs (a leaf node in the graph).
      Parameters:
      data - The scalar value.

    • Value

      public Value(double data, Set<Value> children, String op)
      Creates a new Value with inputs (an intermediate node in the graph).
      Parameters:
      data - The scalar value.
      children - The set of input Values that produced this one.
      op - The operation symbol (e.g. "+", "*") for debugging/display.

  • Method Details

    • add

      public Value add(Value other)
      Addition: d(a+b)/da = 1, d(a+b)/db = 1. Both inputs get the full gradient from the output.
      Parameters:
      other - The value to add.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the sum.

    • add

      public Value add(double other)
      Addition: a + b (double).
      Parameters:
      other - The value to add.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the sum.

    • mul

      public Value mul(Value other)
      Multiplication: d(a*b)/da = b, d(a*b)/db = a. Each input's gradient is scaled by the OTHER input's value. Intuition: if b is large, a small change in a has a big effect on the product.
      Parameters:
      other - The value to multiply by.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the product.

    • mul

      public Value mul(double other)
      Multiplication: a * b (double).
      Parameters:
      other - The value to multiply by.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the product.

    • pow

      public Value pow(double exponent)
      Power: d(x^n)/dx = n * x^(n-1) — the classic calculus power rule.
      Parameters:
      exponent - The exponent.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the result.

    • neg

      public Value neg()
      Negation: -x.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the negated value.

    • sub

      public Value sub(Value other)
      Subtraction: a - b. Implemented as a + (-b).
      Parameters:
      other - The value to subtract.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the difference.

    • sub

      public Value sub(double other)
      Subtraction: a - b (double).
      Parameters:
      other - The value to subtract.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the difference.

    • div

      public Value div(Value other)
      Division: a / b. Implemented as a * (b^-1).
      Parameters:
      other - The value to divide by.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the quotient.

    • div

      public Value div(double other)
      Division: a / b (double).
      Parameters:
      other - The value to divide by.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the quotient.

    • log

      public Value log()
      Log: d(ln(x))/dx = 1/x — used in computing the loss function.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the natural logarithm.

    • exp

      public Value exp()
      Exp: d(e^x)/dx = e^x — the exponential is its own derivative. Used in softmax to convert raw scores into probabilities.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing e^x.

    • relu

      public Value relu()
      ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit): max(0, x). The simplest activation function. If x > 0, pass it through. If x < 0, output 0. Gradient: 1 if x > 0, 0 if x < 0. Acts like a gate.
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the ReLU activation.

    • sigmoid

      public Value sigmoid()
      Sigmoid: 1 / (1 + e^-x). Used for gating mechanisms (output 0 to 1).
      Returns:
      A new Value representing the sigmoid activation.

    • backward

      public void backward()
      Backward(): The heart of learning.

      Step 1: Build a topological ordering of all Value nodes. (If A feeds into B which feeds into C, we need to process C, then B, then A.)

      Step 2: Walk backward through this ordering, applying the chain rule at each node. Each node's _backward() function pushes gradients to its inputs.

      After this runs, every Value in the graph knows its gradient — i.e., how much the final error would change if you nudged that number up a tiny bit.

    • buildTopo

      private void buildTopo(Value v, Set<Value> visited, List<Value> topo)
      Helper to build a topological sort of the graph.
      Parameters:
      v - Current node.
      visited - Set of visited nodes to avoid cycles/revisiting.
      topo - List to append nodes to in topological order.
